description: Central Hudson's Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) is a utility demand response program that pays commercial and industrial customers to reduce electricity usage during peak demand periods. The program operates during the summer season (June 1 through September 30) and offers two distinct enrollment options: a Reservation Payment option with monthly capacity payments and lower performance rates, and a Voluntary Payment option with no capacity payments but higher performance rates for unplanned events. Participants must respond to events called Monday through Friday between 12:00 PM and 8:00 PM, with events lasting up to 4 hours. The program uses Customer Baseline Load (CBL) methodology to calculate actual load reductions. Customers in transmission-constrained areas eligible for the Targeted Demand Response (TDR) program are not eligible for CSRP.

service_territories: Central Hudson service territory in New York's Hudson Valley region
geography.notes: Central Hudson serves approximately 300,000 electric customers and 80,000 natural gas customers in the Mid-Hudson River Valley, covering eight counties including Dutchess, Orange, Putnam, Ulster, Sullivan, Columbia, Greene, and northern Westchester.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is available to customers in Classification No. 2, 3 or 13. Customers must be able to reduce electrical demand by at least 50 kW when requested (based on comparison with similar NY utility programs - specific Central Hudson minimum not explicitly verified).

resource_types: battery storage (eligibility not explicitly confirmed but not excluded)
eligibility.notes: Commercial and industrial customers anywhere in the Central Hudson service territory can participate. Customers in locations eligible for Central Hudson's Targeted Demand Response (TDR) Program are NOT eligible for CSRP - they will be directed to TDR instead. Demand Response participants are required to have a communicating interval meter installed. If an interval meter is not installed prior to the date of application, the participation start date will be July 1st for applications received by May 1st, and August 1st for applications received by June 1st.

notification_methods: not specified - likely email, phone, SMS
notification.notification_notes: Program distinguishes between 'planned' events (21 hours or more notice) and 'unplanned' events (less than 21 hours notice, potentially as little as 2 hours). Unplanned events have higher performance payment rates to compensate for the shorter notice period. The notification timeframes are based on comparable New York utility CSRP programs (NYSEG/RGE reference 21 hours minimum, unplanned events imply shorter notice).

capacity_rate.notes_on_payment_options: Central Hudson CSRP offers two distinct enrollment options with different payment structures. See detailed comparison below.

monthly_reservation_payment.description: Base monthly reservation payment for enrolled capacity during summer season (June-September)

increased_reservation_payment.description: If 5 or more events are called in any control season, the Reservation Payment increases to $1.54/kW-month starting with the month containing the 5th event through the end of September

reservation_payment_option.test_event_requirement: Customers enrolled in the Reservation Payment option are required to participate in a one hour test event per year on a non-holiday weekday from June 1 through September 30

monthly_reservation_payment.description: No monthly reservation payments under Voluntary Payment option

performance_rate.value: varies by enrollment option and event type

planned_event.description: Performance payment for planned events (21+ hours notice) under Reservation Payment option

unplanned_event.description: Performance payment for unplanned events (less than 21 hours notice) under Reservation Payment option

planned_event.description: Performance payment for planned events (21+ hours notice) under Voluntary Payment option

unplanned_event.description: Performance payment for unplanned events (less than 21 hours notice) under Voluntary Payment option

performance_rate.calculation_methodology: Participant incentives are paid based on actual seasonal-average reductions, calculated using the customer baseline load (CBL) baseline methodology. Payment equals the performance payment rate per kWh multiplied by the average kW of load relief provided during the event multiplied by the number of event hours.
performance_rate.notes: Performance rates are sourced from NYSERDA Energy Storage Services Fact Sheet which lists Central Hudson CSRP rates. The Voluntary Payment option offers significantly higher compensation for unplanned events ($1.00/kWh vs $0.50/kWh) to compensate for the lack of monthly reservation payments and shorter notice periods.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Penalty structure not explicitly documented in publicly available sources. Customers enrolled in Reservation Payment option have committed to respond to events, but specific non-performance penalties are not detailed.

payment_structure.payment_comparison_notes: The two enrollment options create different risk-reward profiles: (1) Reservation Payment option provides predictable monthly income ($4/kW/month, or $1.54/kW/month after 5th event) plus moderate performance payments, suitable for customers who can reliably curtail and want stable revenue; (2) Voluntary Payment option has no guaranteed income but offers 2x higher performance rates for unplanned events ($1.00/kWh vs $0.50/kWh), suitable for customers who want flexibility and can respond quickly to higher-paying events.

seasons.notes: Central Hudson may issue requests to reduce usage between June 1st and September 30. If 5 or more events are called in any control season, the Reservation Payment rate changes. Program operates during peak cooling season in New York.

call_windows.notes: CSRP participants must be able to respond to demand response events Monday through Friday between the hours of 12:00 PM (noon) and 8:00 PM. Test events for Reservation Payment customers occur on non-holiday weekdays. Program does not appear to call events on weekends or holidays.

event_parameters.notes: Customers must maintain electric reduction for up to 4 hours during non-test events. Test events are 1 hour in duration. The reference to '5 or more events' in the reservation payment structure suggests the program can call at least 5 events per season, but no explicit maximum is stated. Planned events receive 21+ hours advance notice; unplanned events receive less than 21 hours notice (potentially as little as 2 hours based on typical utility DR programs).

event_triggers.trigger_description: Events are called when Central Hudson needs to maintain system reliability during peak demand periods in the summer months. Events help reduce stress on the electric grid during periods of high usage, which typically occur on hot summer weekdays between noon and 8 PM. The program distinguishes between planned events (foreseeable high demand periods with 21+ hours notice) and unplanned events (unexpected grid stress situations with shorter notice).

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: May 1 for June 1 start date, or June 1 for July 1 start date

enrollment_period.end_date: May 1 (for June 1 start) or June 1 (for July 1 start)

nomination_bidding.notes: Enrollments will be accepted up to May 1st for a June 1st start date and up to June 1st for a July 1st start date. If a communicating interval meter is not installed prior to the date of application, the participation start date will be July 1st for applications received by May 1st, and August 1st for applications received by June 1st. Customers must nominate their enrolled capacity at time of enrollment.

research_notes: Conducted comprehensive web research on Central Hudson's Commercial System Relief Program (CSRP) on 2025-10-11. Research included Central Hudson official sources, NYSERDA technical documents, application forms, tariff references, and comparable New York utility programs (NYSEG, RGE, National Grid). The program has excellent documentation for its dual payment structure: the NYSERDA Energy Storage Fact Sheet provided detailed payment rates for both Reservation Payment and Voluntary Payment options, which is the most critical data for battery optimization modeling. Key finding: the program offers two distinct risk-reward profiles - Reservation option ($4/kW/month capacity + $0.25-0.50/kWh performance) vs Voluntary option ($0 capacity + $0.25-1.00/kWh performance). The 2x higher unplanned event rate ($1.00/kWh) under Voluntary option is notable for fast-responding batteries. Program structure is typical for New York utilities participating in NYISO demand response. Call window (12-8 PM weekdays) aligns well with summer peak pricing periods. Major data gaps include maximum event frequency/duration limits, which are critical for revenue forecasting and state-of-charge management. The mutual exclusivity with TDR program is important - TDR offers higher capacity payments ($27.30/kW/summer) but serves only transmission-constrained areas. Overall data quality is good for payment structure but moderate for operational parameters. Direct contact with Central Hudson (CH.DLM@cenhud.com) or obtaining complete tariff PDF would be needed for comprehensive operational details.

optimization_considerations.payment_structure_analysis: The dual payment structure creates interesting optimization trade-offs for battery operators. Reservation Payment option provides $4/kW/month guaranteed revenue ($16/kW/summer for June-Sept) but lower performance rates and committed response obligation. Voluntary Payment option has higher upside ($1.00/kWh for unplanned events) with no commitment but no guaranteed baseline revenue. For a 1 MW / 4 MWh battery: Reservation option = $4,000/month guaranteed + event revenue; Voluntary option = $0 guaranteed but 2x higher unplanned event revenue.
optimization_considerations.call_window_optimization: 12 PM - 8 PM weekday call window aligns well with NYISO summer on-peak pricing periods (typically 2-6 PM highest prices). Batteries can optimize by: (1) charging overnight/morning off-peak, (2) being available for CSRP events 12-8 PM, (3) potentially capturing energy arbitrage in non-event hours. 4-hour maximum event duration is well-suited for 4-hour batteries.
optimization_considerations.seasonal_constraints: June 1 - September 30 season (4 months) limits annual revenue potential. Battery must optimize across CSRP + energy arbitrage + potential other revenue streams in Oct-May off-season. Summer-only operation simplifies scheduling but limits total annual earnings.
optimization_considerations.notice_period_optimization: Dual-tier notice structure (21+ hours planned vs <21 hours unplanned) with higher unplanned rates rewards fast-responding resources. Batteries with automated control systems can capture the higher $0.50-1.00/kWh unplanned rates more effectively than manual curtailment resources.
optimization_considerations.revenue_uncertainty: Lack of published maximum events/hours per season creates revenue modeling uncertainty. If program calls 5-10 events per summer at 3-4 hours each, revenue potential is moderate. Need historical event data for accurate forecasting.
optimization_considerations.stacking_opportunities: CSRP operates 12-8 PM weekdays June-Sept. Battery can potentially stack: (1) CSRP capacity/performance payments, (2) NYISO energy arbitrage in non-event hours, (3) NYISO ancillary services (regulation, reserves) when not in CSRP events, (4) demand charge management for host facility. Must verify program rules allow revenue stacking.
optimization_considerations.key_question: Is the battery eligible for both CSRP and NYISO wholesale markets simultaneously, or is CSRP participation exclusive? This is critical for revenue optimization modeling.

integration_metadata.battery_specific_notes: Program does not explicitly exclude or confirm battery energy storage system (BESS) eligibility. Generic 'behind-the-meter' language suggests batteries are eligible. Communicating interval meter requirement is standard for batteries. The 50 kW minimum (inferred) is easily met by commercial/industrial batteries. Fast response time (batteries can respond in seconds) is advantageous for capturing higher-paying unplanned events. 4-hour maximum event duration matches common 4-hour battery configurations. CBL methodology for batteries may need special handling since batteries don't have traditional consumption baseline - verification needed. Recommend confirming with Central Hudson: (1) explicit battery eligibility, (2) CBL calculation for batteries, (3) whether discharge-only or charge-and-discharge operations both qualify, (4) any special telemetry or control requirements for batteries, (5) compatibility with simultaneous NYISO wholesale market participation.
integration_metadata.notes: Central Hudson CSRP is a well-structured program with clear dual payment options that create different optimization strategies for battery operators. The Voluntary Payment option's $1.00/kWh unplanned event rate is among the highest found in utility DR programs and particularly attractive for batteries with fast response capability. The weekday-only, summer-only structure and 12-8 PM call window align well with peak price periods in NYISO. Main limitations for optimization modeling are: (1) uncertainty about maximum events/hours per season, (2) lack of historical event frequency data, (3) need to confirm battery eligibility and CBL calculation methodology, (4) uncertainty about revenue stacking with NYISO markets. Recommend prioritizing contact with Central Hudson to obtain historical event data and confirm battery-specific program rules before building optimization model. Overall: Good candidate program for battery optimization with strong performance rates, but need more operational details for accurate revenue forecasting.
